(Same as JS 308 1)
(This course satisfies the new Religion major requirement:- Tradition-Judaism. 
Judaism, one of the oldest religious traditions in the world, is also one of its most perplexing.  Tied, in its own self-understanding, to a specific people that never numbered more than a few million, it nevertheless developed universalistic ideas that profoundly affected Christianity and Islam - two traditions that include billions of people around the world.  In this course, we will begin with the Hebrew Bible - one of the main texts that helped shape Christian and European civilization - and see how its central concepts and narratives evolved and were interpreted over the next 25 centuries as Jews possessed power and faced persecution, pondered God and struggled with nature and reality.  The outcome is a rich panoply of religious practice, sacred texts and inspired ideas that have made Judaism an enduring tradition.)
course_description: Explores the rituals and practices of Judaism, placing them in their historical context and examining the theological concepts that underpin them.
